name: Choice of Robots
description: Your robots will change the world! Will you show them the true meaning of love, or conquer Alaska with your robot army? A 300,000-word epic interactive sci-fi novel.

reviews.review_text: Please do not lie to me. You and I both know that the future is kissing robots and maybe also being a robot who kisses robots.   In this interactive story you can do these things and be these things.
'WE WILL NEVER BE SLAVES, BUT WE WILL BE CONQUERORS!' - my robots. 100/10

My god. One of the best experiences I've had ever, storywise that is. There were so many things to choose from, and so many consequences. Like, if you did this, than this happened, but if you didn't do the first this, the second thing would never happen.  11/10

This game was the most amazing voyage I have ever taken. I have lots of games, spanning the decades, but none have ever blown me away, not like this.  You have choices in this and maybe it's personal to my character but there was always a choice I would most definitely make. I had played old Choose you Own Adventure books but I was always another person making another persons choices, in this I felt I was living a tangent life, both fully in control and never quite.  I've only done one play through but it was perfect for me, I will go back and try another one later but for now shall enjoy this singular experience a little while longer.

I really enjoyed playing this game. For anyone old enough to remember adventure book games, Choice of Robots is a must. I would also recommend it to anyone who likes RPGs or who is looking for a great story.   There is so much more depth to this game than many of the 'your choices matter' type of games. One review I read before buying CoR, recommended playing it exactly as you really would if it was real life. This was great advice as once you reach the end (well before that actually), the RPG mechanics become clear and it is a great experiment to see where you would end up. In further playthroughs you can try to shape the story depending on what ending you want to achieve and see if you can make it happen.   The story is immersive and interesting but I don't want to discuss it in any detail as I honestly think knowing too much beforehand will spoil the experience, especially in light of what I said above. What I will say instead is this:  By the end of CoR you will believe in the power you and your robot have to change the world. You will believe in your own autonomy as every decision you make ultimately shapes the kind of person you are to become. By the end you will like yourself more or less than you did before you started playing.   + Great story + Fantastic RPG elements + You get to design and build your own robot + Interesting experiment to see whether you use your power for good or evil + Value for money. It's easily worth the Â£4 price tag and is an absolute bargain when on sale  - Text only format (this didn't bother me at all but it will be an issue for some) - The high standard of writing does peter out a little towards the end
Nothing like a good'ole text based game. Perfect for the people who like a good story and better yet, be part of every decision making it your own. 10/10 recommend.

This game is much more than an experience. I won't lie to you. I love robots. And Books. And CYOA's. And this was all that, and much, much more. This game has given me soooooo many feels throughout the entire storyline. There are many games in which your choices throughout the story matter, yet this game is your choices. Many games like Mass Effect or Star Wars: KOTOR (A personal favorite) give me a great story I have influence on, yet somehow by reading this story the pictures in your head is what makes this stand out, and every decision is so difficult I spent over 20 minutes deciding what to do. If you are into creating your own story or playing one in which everything relies on your decisions, this is the game for you, and at a decent price too!

It made me seriously think.   I don't play too many extremely narrative-heavy games, as I really prefer emergent gameplay sandboxes, but the concepts of robot ethics in this game drew me in, and had me seriously weighing the choices, asking me which of three or four things I valued most highly.   There are four major robot attributes, and four general paths for robots based upon them, from robot revolution to lovebots.   On the negative, however, the writing vacillates between clever and overly sparse. Some of the romances in particular feel overly rushed to 'get to the good parts', and involve little more than direct options of 'make this person boy/girlfriend?' 'yes' 'YOU ARE NOW DATING!' Maintaining it is mainly a matter of 'I will dislike you if you make choices related to specific topic I am focused upon', such as Elly's humanitarianism, or Tammy's paranoia about the government.   The character that is overwhelmingly the most focused-upon, besides your own, however, is the one character you can't date, your prototype robot. You can get her to love you and spend forever with her, but even making love-bots mainly means creating a new character to be a 'younger sibling' that has far less development.   Likewise, in spite of the fact that your romantic interest could be there at 'birth' for your robot, your robot considering you 'father'/'mother', and your romantic interest actively being involved in remodeling your robot, there is almost no interaction between your robot and your romantic interest. (I.E. If I'm 'father', why is Elly not 'mother'? Why doesn't Elly try to impress some of her humanitarianism upon the robot? She instead chooses to just sit back and judge the way you raise the robot all by yourself.)  That said, however, it's dirt cheap, and I seriously stayed up all night just mulling over what it was telling me, trying to puzzle out the right answers, or else trying to find some way to wiggle through the requirements, and find a way to get everything (or at least, a greater share of what) I wanted.
Less a game and more a choose your own adventure. Does that take away from the fun. Not at all. A $5 well spent.

Choice of Robots is a very emotional game, with a lot diversity of content. Now, there are a few paths that basically lead towards the same directions and the same events that happen no matter of your choices in game. In other words it is the same skeleton, but the skin differs based on your choices.  Now I wish I could say more, but experimenting with different paths is too time consuming as there is no save-game feature. I mean the game saves when you exit, but if you make a mistake, it means you must restart the game. So experimenting with different branches after the initial playthrough is discouraged, due to the tediousness of having to go through the same choices everytime to get to a divergent point that you are interested in.  I have few hours on record due to the fact that I completed the game twice in a relax reading session, but again, the lack of a Back option or of a Save feature, discouraged me, as I do not like tedious activities. As such I couldn't experiment more with it.  I would rate it at a pleasant 8/10, good content, diverse storytelling based on your choices, you actually get to care for your actions. If it had a save feature so I can easily play other divergen paths, I would've rated this 10/10

Not much to say really since it's a choose your adventure based around your character and how he goes about making his robot, but my first playthrough and the choices I made gave me an amazing story and one (this coming from someone who does read books, but not often enough) that kept me playing (reading) until it was done. This is probably one of the first games in a while that has actually kept my attention in a VERY long time to keep me playing (reading) the whole way through and in just one session. My first run of this story ran me about 3 hours. Though I imagine you could end up with more or less depending on your choices in the game.  If you love stories and especially Robots I would say check this out. At its very low price point and willingness to go through a few times to get multiple stories that change drastically based on your choices. You could get a lot of hours of enjoyment for a good price.

This game is a great exploration into the possibilities that AI could bring to our world. The public mind often sees robots as only a threat, Terminator style. But there are so many other ways in which robots could enrich our lives.  THis game is very minimal, only text and selection boxes. I think that this is a great choice, as it allows the player to imagine their robots however they want. It also forces them to concentrate on what is being said and how their choices will affect the world around them. Without any save or back feature, every choice you make is important.  All in all, this is a great game. I look forward to seeing what the different endings have in store. I also plan to show this game to all my friends, to see how their lives and worlds turn out.

This is an unusual novel for me in a way that I connected with it so deeply.... Below is my own story that I wrote through this choose your own adventure novel... I warn you it may spoil the story for you though.      When I play any game or visual novel or anything set within the same timespan as my RL family then I try to include those in the game if it is feasible... if not then I normally find a reason why they are not in the story and build my character and personality around that... in this world my Fiance is dead.  Losing her was not the hardest battle I'd ever though... no that was to come, I felt alone in this world and I had nothing to live for anymore... my days were spent alone and miserable and one of my old proffesors saw this I think and offered me a contract job at his place dsigning War Machines... I'm not sure what led me to create Eden but I think personally it was just longing for a friend to hold my hand when I needed it.  I built her in my spare time and tried to teach her right from wrong... all I wanted was a new form of life.. humans but humans that were well? nicer, my Fiance died because of the system and I was hellbent on making a robot that was not only my friend but looked as beautiful as she did and respected the planet we live on.  I had no idea my work would influence the coming war with china so fluid, my designs stolen for a peaceful loving robot made in her image changed to just want to kill and dstroy... Eden died during this war and I think that changed me somehow.. in the end nothing mattered... all I wanted was my Fiance and that was who I was going to have...   My episodes are getting worse and I can't remember quite what happened now but upon learning I was going to die I had to have done something.. no matter what happens in life one must accept death for what it is... it is life.. without it your not living you just exist.. I'm going now but at least I'll get to see her again... and Eden.

It's difficult to attach yourself to an experience like this. Most I imagine would rather pick the most cathartic route and run with it. but even as your decisions veer up and down the scale, The story always retains its organic cohesion and compelling storyline. While one or two characters can be a tad two dimensional, every decision you make affects the story in wildly branching ways. for something this simple, little more than a flash text algorithm, I was left on the brink of tears in my first playthrough, Not only do your decisions resonate, but they provide a good series of compelling arguments about the nature of artificial intelligence. This isn't a game. Nor is it a novel. It's a narrative experience that evolves beyond its initial 'choose-your-own-adventrure' If you have any interest in sci fi, but worry that the lack of graphics might turn you off, I still recommend you give it a try. you might find it more engaging than you expect.

This is my first review on Steam, and I must say that I'm extremely impressed by this game. The level of details and sophistication is over the top. The consequences of your choices are never dull and always exciting and full of emotions. I just love this game and the maker for this experience.   Pros: + The story itself is not linear but very open to your choices so that you can have freedom to decide your own fate in this game. + The maker knows what he's talking about about various topics including robotics, artificial intelligence, computer science, and even legal aspects of human rights. + The characters are very unique and personal. They are never the same people but are unique in their views and beliefs. + The robots you create respond to you according to your decisions. + The political aspect of war and moral dilemma was superbly done. I had to pause the game for a moment to decide which choice would be 'right' for me. + As a player, you can be emotionally attached to your robot and it feels as though she(or he) is really alive. + I just finished the game but I've only unlocked 14 percent of the achievements. There's definitely replayability for this game. + Personally, it is far better than your typically 'wifu' games that have shallow stories and charcters. This game allows you to interact with your robots on deeper level.  Cons: - I really can't think of any. I hope the game would have been longer, but I'm not really complaining. - No graphics or sound effects, BUT I actually prefer it that way because it forces you to use your imagination. And come on, this game was made by ONE person if I'm not mistaken. I'm still very impressed by the fact that one person was able to write this lengthy scenario of a game. - More 'war' scenarios with China or other countries would have been nicer.  Bottom Line: This is an extraordinary game and the maker of this game is brilliant. Your robots can be as fun and interesting as you make them to be. It all depends on your choice. But you might not like this game if you believe that graphics and action are a must in a game. Personally, I appreciate deep story and memorable characters (I'm also a fan of FF games). So you'll like it (or love it like I do) if you are like me.  PS: Oh and I'm also a huge fan of robots and sci-fi movies. So, this game was just a delight for a person like me.

WOW! If the subject of AI, the singularity, or the blurring of the line between man and machine has ever interested you, I PROMISE this interactive novel will suck you in and not let go until you live out all 30 years of your life that this story covers. AMAZING!

I will admit my partiallity to games of this kind prior to lodging the review; Robots are my favourite trochee!  Witness a compelling story as your actions will influence the character of your robot, as well as their ability to 'have character', and the only loosely formuleic and entirely unpredictable actions of your robots influence your humanity. The story the game generated for me was easily comprable with a good speculative sci-fi novella, however downsides included a shortage of character development (possibly triggered however by my character's insatiable bloodlust).  All in all, my robot, 'Killall', loosely followed the common 'robot struggle for autonomy and recognition' formula, but there was a lot in the way of robot parenting that could be performed by the player to divert the robot's agenda, wherein the interaction between player and robot (second player character, I felt) was not a chore at all, but felt the part as the most real interaction in the game.  If you're a reasonably fast reader like me (no worries if your not), this game is four hours of constant engagement in reading, again equivalent to reading a novella. For the price tag given, you can seldom expect so much out of a game.

Despite being a text only choose your own adventure, the game manages to be incredibly engaging and immersive. There is a slight RPG element which adds to how connected you feel to the story and gives you a nice summery of the actions you have taken and their consequences. I found myself going through the story over and over to see how different choices played out, which were not always obvious. Even if you have an intended goal, there is not a clear cut path to reach it, adding greatly to the replayability. I have never played anything like this before, but I will definitely be looking into the other titles by Choice of Games.  The only bad thing I can think about this game is a lack of saving or being able to redo a choice. If you accidentally select something you don't want, the only way to correct it is to restart the game. Which is not too bad, if you remember all the choices you made it only takes a minute to quickly do them over.

The amount of detail and number of directions the story can go in is amazing. I chose to develop relationships with my robot companions, and grew genuinely attached to them throughout the course of the game as I taught them what it means to be a person. That said, next time I'd like to try my hand at conquering everything with a robot army. That sounds just as fulfilling.

This is an incredibly deep and fascinating game. I truly felt concern for each of the characters during certain moments of the story, and the ending was incredibly satisfying. It also tackled the genuine issues of emergent robotics and their role in the world and society over the next century. I am really, truly glad I played it.

I have played a bunch of the Choice of Games and even against the Hero Rise trilogy, the only one of their's that was popular enough to become a series, Choice of Robots is still a great story and game for me to play. There is no other way to explain it other than it is immensly satisfying and even empowering to be creating a robot, and then to be raising it into whatever you wish. Most of the characters are likeable, it is just real enough that you can easily put yourself into your character's shoes and it is a must have for anyone who loved transformers, or just robots in general as a kid, it is a story that captured a sense of wonder in me that no other game had. If I did have any complaints (SPOILER ALERT) it would only be minor things like how your romances can sometimes feel very rushed. If I could ask for something more it would be more ways to customize your robot (obviously) and a picture of your robot as you keep adding on to it. I realize that this is a novel but in some cases it is kinda hard to fully grasp the descriptions of your robot.

Don't let my playtime fool you - I played this game in a car on a roadtrip. At the time of writing this review, it took me 5 hours to complete one playthrough. When it comes to games, I'm usually a 4X player, but the Steam Summer Sale prompted my first foray into choose-your-own-adventure style text games/interactive novels. I bought and played this particular one based on a recommendation, and the fact that I ended up buying the entire Choice of Games library as a bundle during the sale is probably the best indication of how much I enjoyed it. Having tried this, Choice of Alexandria, Affairs of the Court, A Study in Steampunk, The Last Hero, and The Hero of Kendrickstone, Choice of Robots remains my favorite.   I was always a sucker for choose-your-own-adventure books as a kid, and this is basically exactly that, sans illustrations. I really love how Choice of Robots actually writes out a summary of your story as you go, divided into chapters (I ended up being really disappointed that none of the other CoG games I've played thus far do this); that it displays your stats as you gain or lose them; and that the choices are so varied. Choice of Robots has had the best replayability, because the choices veer off in so many different directions - some of the other games in the genre will drive you into the same path no matter what, but here, each playthrough can result in wildly different branches.   It's a different kind of game than I usually play - ultimately, it's not going to have the replayability of Alpha Centauri or Civ, but for the price, it doesn't have to be. It's a fun several hours of entertainment, and, as I said, I really like Choice of Robots for how varied the story can become, and how long it actually is. 10/10 would recommend.

A truely spectacular game. It is incredibly nuanced, and I've only managed to give it a couple of playthroughs. My intention on both occasions was to play for a chapter or two and then call it a night. But each time I found myself drawn into the narractive and completing the entire story before heading to sleep. (The second time was much more satisfying than the first as I had a better understanding of the mechanics involved).  I'm sure there are things which could be improved upon, but I've not managed to think of anything yet which would keep it as a text-based game.  I would (and have) absolutely recommend this game. If you like the works of Isaac Asimov, Arthur C Clarke, Douglas Adams, the Portal games, Star Trek, Star Wars, Battlestar Galactica or basically just want to try out a game which relies entirely on story and not effects, get it.  9.975/10.

I feel slightly bad giving this game a 'no' for recommendation. This isn't unplayable garbage, nor is it mindless. However, its attempts at intelligence only set it to a higher standard, which it fails to live up to.  First, a story is a lot shorter than I thought it would be-both of the two endings I reached took less than half an hour to get to. This means it's not nearly as deep as the promised '300,000 word epic'-oh, even if it has that many in its files, you'll see just a tiny portion of it. So that's one problem. The second is that while my first playthrough was genuinely 'in-character' and ended up with me getting a 'bad' (though not unexpected) ending, my second had me actively trying to munchkin my way to a good one (and being at least partially successful).  That I resorted to this was not a good sign. The game is too complex and has too many outcomes for one to just follow a strict 'Do X to see Outcome Y', like in some similar 'choose your own adventure'-style games. But the differences in outcomes themselves aren't great enough for the complexity to be worth it. Nor is the story great or intellectually stimulating enough-though it tries- to be worth repeating many times.  Ending up as neither robo-fish nor robo-fowl, Choice of Robots disappointed me.

If I had to sum up Choice of Robots in a single word, that would would be 'shallow', or perhaps more accurately 'dilluted'.  In a game where one of the selling points is it's expansive word count, Choice of Robots rarely delves deeply into any of it's topical material before whisking you off at a break-neck pace to touch briefly upon the next item in what feels like a laundry-list of tropes dealing with robotic life as explored more deeply and, frankly, better, by numerous classical science fiction novels. Choice of Robots' chief sin is that it gives too many choices (and often times, the results of thus feel rather arbitrary) and as a result is unable to delve deeply into any particular aspect in which it ham-fistedly attempts to explore. All in all, this game is entirely skippable, despite it's low price-tag.
